This video contains too much equivocation fallacy for me (calling two different things by the same name). First the author equates increased velocity to hardship ("getting one mile east in a minute is a lot harder than getting there in a day"), then in the same sentence he equates distance to time ("so one mile east and one minute in the future is way more DISTANT than one mile east and a day in the future"). So in one fell swoop he equivocates distance, time, distance's time derivative velocity, and the energy (hardship) required to accelerate to a velocity in order to cover the distance more quickly. The author then implies that because it's impossible to instantaneously change position, then all positions other than one's present position are "super DISTANT" in the instantaneous present (now). This statement is partially true in the sense that distance (delta x) is a non-measurable entity in the present, and one can only measure distance by travelling there, and the rate of this travel is limited by the speed of light. But just because space is a non-measurable entity in the instantaneous present, it's a non-sequitur to imply that space is a non-existent entity in the instantaneous present. Space still exists, it's just that you can't get there without time. This doesn't give you leave to arrogantly claim that the only space that exists in the instantaneous present is you. Space exists, but you can't travel faster than the speed of light to get there. No, the volume occupied by the Washington Monument doesn't cease to exist just because you are not physically there. The author then concludes that a minute is "farther away" (distance) than an hour, another non-sequitur. His equivocation of terms between distance and time essentially renders velocity as a non-entity. In other words, how can velocity (delta x divided by delta t) ever even exist if x and t are the SAME THING (which the author calls "distance")? The author then caps off the nonsense by claiming that things travelling at the speed of light cover zero distance, which is empirically false.

What if I graph a time dimension and a space dimension and then plot two points: one a meter away and a second into the future and another at the same distance--a meter--but two seconds into the future?  I can easily draw two right-triangles and use the pythagorean theorem to calculate the distance from me to each of the points in question.  I find that the point one meter and one second into the future is sqrt(1m^2 + 1s^2) away while the other is sqrt(1m^2 + 4s^2) away from me.  Surely the second point is more distant in the way that was described in the video.

Yes actually. Special relativity shows that objects moving relative to you shorten in their direction of motion. This means that when you're travelling to your friend's house (we'll ignore that the earth is round), everything around you shortens. This isn't noticeable at low speeds, though; only at speeds comparable to the speed of light does it really matter.

Here's the idea. Define two points stationary relative to each other, and measure the distance between them. You expect this quantity to be invariant. That is, no matter where you are or how fast you're moving, you'll always measure that distance to be the same. Einstein showed in SR that this isn't correct; distances change with velocity. He defined a new "distance" that was truly invariant called the space-time interval that included both space and time. This is what the video describes.

I should have been clearer:
Δs²=(Δr²)-(Δt²) Or, by some notations:
Δs²=(Δt²)-(Δr²)
Δt is the difference in time between two events, and Δr is the difference in spatial position between the events. Notice that this means Δs² can be positive or negative. For the first notation, if Δs² is negative, it's possible to pass through both events (you wouldn't have to travel faster than light to do so.) This geometric view of relativity can be confusing and it's best to learn the algebraic view first.

Ignoring time as a dimension and just looking for regular space "distance" You'd get Δr^2=(Δx)^2+(Δy)^2+(Δz)^2.
What this really is is an "invariant" quantity. the idea is that no matter what coordinate system, that value Δr^2 is always the same. In relativity this doesn't work. The length of an object depends on velocity for example. Instead you have an invariant quantity called the "space-time interval," and its value is 
Δs^2=Δr^2-Δt^2
Which is always the same regardless of coordinate system.

What he's getting at here is that travelling close to the speed of light causes your time relative to a stationary observer to slow down. And if you're a photon travelling at the speed of light, you basically don't experience time at all because it's slowed down to zero. And if no time has gone by then no distance can ever be traversed - making that zero too. Distance = speed x time. So, if: D = speed of light x 0, then: D = 0. That's what this video is trying to say.

Bottom line: normal distance in 2 space dimensions: d^2 = x^2 + y^2 (pythagorean theorem). In space time make the plus negative and define y to be time. That is the definition of distance in special relativity. It's weird but the fact is that we can't make any meaningful statements about all reference frames in special relativity unless we define distance in precisely this way.

rule: distance is the measurement of how hard it is to get from point A to point B

You can make up definitions for 'distance' all you want.  But the reason the moon is further away is 1) actual distance (measured in, say, meters) and 2) difference in potential energy (that is, the amount required to escape the earth's gravity well minus how much is gained by falling into the moon's; this is measured in, say, joules).  Actual distance plus gravitational difference accounts for all the information about how far away something is (i.e. time to get there and energy to get there)

@dragsigma It WOULD be one mile away in space.  If you drew a graph with only space axes, then a line connecting you with a point one mile east would simply be a line one mile long.  Spacetime includes a time axis.  A line connecting you with a point one mile east right now would have the property that the slope of the line would give your speed.  Speed is distance over time.  Time=zero implies speed=infinity.  In order to reach one mile east right now you would have to travel at infinite speed.

@1lAllanl1 To find the distance between two points in n-dimensional euclidian space, you just use the distance theorem, which is basically some version of the pythagorean theorem, i.e., distance squared = sum of the squares of the dimensions, e.g., d^2=x^2+y^2+z^2.  In minkowski space, you do the same thing, but one of the terms in the distance formula is negative—the time term. So d^2=–t^2+x^2+y^2+z^2.  This video gives a nice analogy for why this makes sense.

@samsledje But for someone outside the train, watching it move fast, the same photon is seen to move not only up and down but sideways as well. Thus it is travelling a distance greater than 2d (expressed as >2d). But Einstein said the speed of the photon must be constant! So the time elapsed for the outside observer is >2d/c. The faster you move, the slower time passes! If you do this exactly you get the famous Lorentz formula for time dilation.

@samsledje Now he imagined that this photon clock was on a train travelling very fast. To someone on the train however, the photon clock that they are holding in their hand is not moving relative to them - when you throw a ball into the air on a bus, it falls back down in front of you - it doesn't crash into the back of the bus! This is because the ball is moving at the same speed as you are (which is the same speed as the bus). Thus to the person on the train the time elapsed, t, equals 2d/c.

@samsledje Essentially, Einstein realised that  the speed of light must be a constant, no matter what. This meant that it must be a constant in all frames of reference. Einstein took this idea and ran with it: 

He imagined a photon clock, an object which fires a photon up to a mirror a distance d away. The photon is reflected off the mirror and arrives back at where it started. The time it takes for it to do this is equal to the total distance travelled (2d), divided by the speed of light (c).

@samsledje Usually, when we measure the distance between two points we measure their distance in space and assume that that distance is fact and thus the same in all reference frames. (e.g. if you rotated sideways you'd still see the distance as being exactly the same). But in reality, when moving, that's simply not true - the only thing that remains constant in all references is the separation in space-time. @samsledje The mistake in his explanation is his lack of clarity in saying what he means by 'distance'. In reality, Distance through space-time squared = Distance through space squared minus Distance through time squared. In all frames of reference, distance through spacetime of the same event is conserved.

The way the maths works out, if something is observed to be travelling at the speed of light, its space part and time part cancel out making zero. So the distance through space-time is zero.

@Barthoization For the light (photon), the distance is always zero.
Length contraction (derived from the Lorentz transformation) uses the formula below:
L = L0 * SqRoot(1-(v^2/c^2))

For v=c, we have:
L = L0 * SqRoot (1 - 1)
L= L0 * SqRoot(0)
L = L0 * 0

For whatever the initial distance L0 is, L will always be 0.

Yeah, no. How far away something is depends only on the distance between the points. How fast you get there doesn't affect how far you travel, assuming you are traveling between two stationary points (well, stationary relative to yourself at least). Certainly, once you add in all the wacky stuff like space being curved or wormholes it could get complicated, but how far away something is does not change no matter what speed you are going (again, unless the two points are themselves moving).

Explanation: Time is not fixed – the speed of light is. Since R = D/T, and rate is fixed relative to the speed of light, then to ‘move faster’ in space you must ‘move slower’ through time, thus increasing your ‘time distance.’ Also, the amount of force over any time required to go from A to B would be the same at any speed (ignoring entropy blahblah). But since time moves slower at faster speeds, the force required increases, making faster travel ‘harder.’
